Abstract

The institutionalized separation between form, structure and material, deeply embedded in modernist design theory, paralleled by a methodological partitioning between modeling, analysis and fabrication, resulted in geometric-driven form generation. Such prioritization of form over material was carried into the development and design logic of CAD (Computer Aided Design). Today, under the imperatives and growing recognition of the failures and environmental liabilities of this approach, contemporary design culture is experiencing a shift of paradigm towards a material-aware design approach (Oxman,2007,Mele and Block,2010). This research aims to examine conceptual and modeling representations of an extended performative materiality and outline key areas of design applications for computationally enabled form generation.

Title: “Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”
Applicant: Pantazis Evangelos
Preferred Professorship at  ITA: Assistant Chair  of  Building  Structure,prof.Dr.  P. Block  in  collaboration with  Chair  for 
Computer Aided Architectural Design, prof. Dr  L. Hovestadt and/or Chair  for Architecture and Digital Fabrication, prof F. 
Gramazio and M. Kohler.
Keywords:  topology  optimization,  material  distribution  method,  architectural  design,  digital  fabrication,  additive 
manufacturing, rapid prototyping, structural morphology, design explorer, design operator, variable  property fabrication, 
performance-based design
1. Summary
Research topic: The institutionalized separation between form, structure and material, deeply embedded in modernist 
design theory, paralleled by a methodological partitioning between modeling, analysis and fabrication, resulted in 
geometric-driven form generation. Such prioritization of form over material was carried into the development and design 
logic of CAD (Computer Aided Design). Today, under the imperatives and growing recognition of the failures and 
environmental liabilities of this approach, contemporary design culture is experiencing a shift of paradigm towards a 
material-aware design approach (Oxman,2007,Mele and Block,2010). This research aims to examine conceptual and 
modeling representations of an extended performative materiality and outline key areas of design applications for 
computationally enabled form generation.
Performance Based Design and Variable Material Property Distribution: Design can be described as a process of 
emergence and discovery resulting from the definition of the constraints, their relationships, and the design problem. 
Constraints can help to focus design exploration through formulating the boundaries of available resources (Dritsas, 
2004). While they may initially prove to be a limitation, over the course of the design process they can evolve into a 
driver for innovative design solutions. These solutions incorporate multiple manifestations of form, departing from the 
point of view of geometry, material selection, performance, and construction (Kilian,2006). Each manifestation promotes 
its very own method of process and media of representation. However, in some cases representations may be generated 
which support multiple manifestations simultaneously while reciprocally informing each other (Sass and Griffith,2006). 
Based on computational geometry, we can define certain analytical forms of representation in the form of “enabling 
representations” which associate geometry to performance by means of generative computation processes (Oxman,
2007). Such enabling representations become design tools  offering multiple feasible translations based on a unifying 
code of interpretation. These tools are intermediate in nature, a property which renders them generative. Beyond the 
notion of performance-driven interpretations based on computational geometry methods, this work will also deal with 
computational analysis as a source for strategizing material distribution in design artifacts. This method promotes design 
manifestations which are not concerned with the notion of “build-ability” to begin with, but they rather let formal 
statements be informed by behavior and performance which result in the gradient distribution of material qualities and 
effects (Oxman, N.,2010). 
Goals: This proposal, will engage topology optimization and material distribution methods in order to investigate 
innovative architectural and design applications materialized by using additive fabrication technologies and functionally 
graded materials. Rather than just breaking down the design into a series of digitally fabricated componentized elements 
aiming at either simplified and straightforward or more complex assemblies, we suggest an alternative approach favoring 
material distribution over strategies of composition. We will look into tunable mechanical properties created through 
structural calibration or multi-material composition and will attempt to prove such an approach through the development 
and realization of irregular digital geometries across multiple manufacturing scales. Each scheme will focus on specific 
topologic, geometric and material constraints relating to the corresponding application.
2. Methodology
Performance driven design will be investigated as a theoretical and technical framework by which to model, analyze and 
fabricate objects with graded properties designed to correspond to multiple and continuously varied functional 
constraints. In order to implement this approach as a fabrication process, we will focus on additive fabrication techniques 
such as rapid manufacturing with Polyjet Matrix Technology and customized fused deposition modeling. Experimental 
designs employing suggested theoretical and technical frameworks, methods and techniques will be developed, 
discussed and demonstrated. They will promote product customization, rapid augmentation and variable property 
prototyping. The research will be held and executed using both existing and custom developed software and hardware 
platforms, with the aim of demonstrating the principles of variable property modeling in the design of products, building 
components, and potentially larger constructions.  Three design schemes illustrated by corresponding design products 
will be presented: a) Surface and Material: table design , b) Function and design: Bridge structure c) Form and forces: 
Self standing roofing structure.Each will demonstrate the approach in different scales while utilizing different modeling 
strategies for the control of material properties based on performance constraints. In particular we will try to look into the 
topic through the following key aspects:
2.1.Virtual Modeling-Design Operators for variable property modeling 
121212_RESEARCH STATEMENT_”Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”




                                    

                            

                                            

            
                                    
                                    
-Topology optimization/ Material distribution method:  The topology, shape, and size of the structure are not represented 
by standard parametric functions but by a set of distributed functions defined on a fixed design domain. These functions 
in turn represent a parametrization of the stiffness tensor of the continuum and it is the suitable choice of this 
parametrization which leads to the proper design formulation for topology optimization. This method defines shape in 
terms of a material density and geometry by what amounts to a raster representation as seen in computer graphics. 
(Bendsoe, M.P. and Sigmund, O., 2003), Recent developments in material technologies and fabrication enable the 
realization of this notion. While given materials are bonded with the 'classical' notion of design, material design and 
"functionally graded materials" imply a broader range of material usage and design orientation. In terms of the optimizer 
tool, heuristic methods will be employed as they are most flexible in complying with abstractly defined constraints and 
optimization objectives. Their flexibility lies in their ability to formulate a “fitness” or optimization function which does not 
have to come in the form of an explicit analytic formula. In contrast to gradient based methods who call for smooth 
functions, these methods can handle a complex analysis process, often functioning as a black box, which in our case will 
be provided via the Finite Element analysis. Heuristic methods for evolutionary computation include Genetic Algorithms 
(GA) (Goldberg 1989) often met in engineering problems (Chatzi et al. 2011, Fuggini et al. 2012), Particle Swarm 
Optimization (PSO) methods (Kennedy 1995) and several other alternatives (Michalewicz 1996). Evolutionary 
computation has been previously used in architectural design optimization (Holzer et al. 2005) as well as in linking 
optimal design to structural performance criteria (von Buelow et al. 2010, Rajan 1995). In those works however the focus 
was on given material properties often accompanied by the associated limitations in selected geometries. This research 
will attempt to shift the attention on the alteration of the material properties based on the implied geometrical and/or 
functional parameters and vice versa.
-Finite Element analysis FEM-FEA: The finite element method (FEM) is a numerical technique for solving partial 
differential or integral equations over complex domains. It is widely used in any field where numerical solution procedures 
for initial/boundary value problems are needed to meet design and analysis needs. The FE method has become the 
most successful approximation method in engineering (Babuska 1973). Although the following list is not exhaustive, 
applications are met in structural mechanics, mechanical engineering, mechanics of materials, fluid mechanics, 
biomechanics, electrical engineering, aeronautical engineering, and environmental engineering and science. The aim is 
to simulate physical behavior under structural and/or environmental loading cases. The method operates by applying a 
mesh discretization of a continuous domain into a set of discrete sub-domains, usually called elements. Elements 
comprise a set of different entities, linear, 2D, or 3D solid elements, chosen according to the nature of the problem at 
hand, which enables partitioning a large problem into smaller parts that can be individually analyzed. Several attempts 
have so far tried to couple FE analysis with optimization schemes, mainly aiming at optimization of structural 
performance or topology optimization with a target of minimal weight (Adeli and Cheng  1994, Xie and Steven 1997). We 
will follow this paradigm and try to further enhance the finite element method in an environment of material property 
gradation goals like variable elasticity and minimal weight. The translation of a conceived!geometry!expressed in a CAD 
form into a structural entity to be analyzed by FE analysis can be enabled by the use of voxels (Gröning et al. 2009).
-Voxels/ Maxels (material-voxels): Voxels are digital volume elements that are analogous to 2D pixels whose position is 
defined by their proximity to other voxels. Voxels are thus good at representing regularly sampled spaces that are non-
homogeneously filled. They are currently used in the visualization and analysis of medical and scientific data but have 
yet to be implemented in the context of form-generation. Maxel is a term introduced in 2005   to describe a physical voxel 
(a portmanteau of the words 'material' and 'voxel'), which defines the build resolution of either a rapid prototyping or rapid 
manufacturing process, or the resolution of a design produced by such fabrication means (Miyamoto et al. 1999). It is 
also used in the context of the additive manufacturing processes (such as stereolithography, selective laser sintering, 
fused deposition modeling, etc.). We regard the “Voxel” to be a useful aid in rendering physically our digitally calculated 
models, through the use of rapid prototyping processes 
The applicant is already in contact with the Chair of Structural Engineering at ETH Zurich, lead by Prof. Dr. E. Chatzi, 
who has experience in the combined use of optimization methodologies with structural analysis methods for the 
simulation of complex materials.
2.2. Physical Modeling- Tooling environment for variable property rapid prototyping
Although there has been a significant development in additive fabrication technologies since they first appeared in the 
mid 1980’s, most of them still serve as prototyping technologies in the building industry.  Although they have provided the 
opportunity to create complex models they have been also very limiting, often reducing material selection to an array of 
highly brittle, inelastic materials (Sachs,  Cima, et al., 1993). Thus, based on the latest achievements of Polyjet Matrix 
TM technology, which allows for the creation of dual material prototypes, we will focus on the varying property layered 
manufacturing technology. The advantages of printing material with varied properties such as density or stiffness 
variation are most significant as they can potentially enhance the mechanical performance of a given component while 
reducing the overall amount of material required for its production (Oxman,2010). Accompanying an increased motivation 
in the production of structural and highly functional graded parts using additive technologies, and inspired by pioneering 
research into 3D fabrication of scaffolds for tissue engineering (Sun et al. 2004), our approach aims to combine 3D 
printing with recent advancements achieved in material science and tissue engineering (Chua et al. 1999, Freyman et al. 
2001, Cheah et al. 2003a,b, 2004). The distribution of material properties as a function of their performance 
requirements at micro structural scale is elegantly exemplified with the development and application of functional 
gradient materials (FGMs).We will try to implement and review the following techniques:
121212_RESEARCH STATEMENT_”Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”




                                    

                            

                                            

            
                                    
                                    
-Rapid Manufacturing/ Polyjet MatrixTM Technology (Objet Geometries/): PolyJet Matrix technology is capable extruding 
multiple photopolymers simultaneously and allows for the generation of composite material prototypes of varying 
stiffness. With the use of this technology we will investigate the potential of altering the stiffness of one structure in critical 
points so that we can improve its overall performance.
-Fused Deposition Modeling/ Maker Bot (or similar custom 3d printer)& Kuka 6-axis robotic arm: Variable Fused 
Deposition Modeling will attempt to define a novel deposition technology, which offers gradation control of materials 
within one 3D print with the aim of increasing mechanical efficiency and reducing energy input. This technology will use a 
robotic arm and a dynamic material feeder which will be able to mix and feed the prescribed material quantities/ratios. By 
doing that, we hope to make a first step towards the introduction of FGMs into additive manufacturing, as well as freeing 
this technique from the 2d sequential layering (added degrees of freedom if we attach a printing nozzle as the end 
effector of the robot).
2.3. Functionally Graded Materials
In Material Science, functionally graded materials (FGMs) are characterized by the gradual variation in composition and 
structure over their volume, resulting in corresponding changes of the material’s properties. Such materials can be 
designed and engineered for a specific set of functions and applications.(Suresh and Mortensen 1998). Functionally 
graded materials are a new generation of engineering materials characterized by compositional and structural variation 
across their volume unit, resulting in property changes in the material such as mechanical shock resistance, thermal 
insulation, catalytic efficiency and relaxation of thermal stress. The concept of FGMs is revolutionary in the areas of 
material science and mechanics as it allows one to fully integrate between material and structural considerations in the 
final design of structural components. (Stoneham and Harding 2009). As part of this research, functionally graded 
materials will be the enabling tool for the realization of innovative designs and new structural forms.
3. Aims and Objectives
This research aims at presenting the prospect for an emerging professional profile of informed tool-making in order to 
promote a new model for contemplating form and practicing design. A new process, based on the gradient alteration of 
material properties is suggested as a general approach to the design of building components. Finite Element analysis will 
be the tool used for the simulation of potential designs and heuristic methods such as genetic algorithms or particle 
swarm optimization will be used as the optimizer tools in order to achieve optimal design under the desired geometric, 
topological and material constraints. We will emphasize on the generative potential that exists within analytical tools for 
geometrical evaluation, as we aim to prove that such tools may inform the designer in her/his search for formal 
expression and that they contain opportunities to transcend the geometric-centered description of form by linking it to 
performance criteria (spatial, structural, environmental, etc). Analytical tools will be computed as geometrical statements. 
These statements will serve as multi-objective representations between geometry and performance, geometry and 
manufacturing as well as geometry and construction. For the materialization of such statements this work will examine 
the PolyJet Matrix technology, which by extruding multiple photopolymers simultaneously, can allow for the variation of 
material properties within one 3d print. Moreover, we will review FDM (fused deposition modeling) technology, a solid-
based fabrication process, by a) introducing multiple extrusion heads and b) by attaching them (along with the rest of the 
hardware) as an end effector on a 6-axis robotic arm.
4. Contribution
Computational tools associated with structural performance evaluation, simulation and optimization (FEM, Evolutionary 
computation) are traditionally utilized outside the design process or in parallel to it. The model, presented in this paper, 
seeks to integrate processes of performance evaluation with form generation by means of computational geometry. It will  
build upon research from material science and structural tectonics under novel fabrication tectonics, in order to suggest 
an approach for modeling and materializing a 3d object, where internal structure/composition of the form can be 
represented by the corresponding variance of different material gradients. This ability can expand the potential of 
prototyping, since the varying properties allows for optimization of material properties relative to their structural 
performance and for more accurate evaluations of the intended final product (stress testing). If such a prospect is 
legitimate, then it is the knowledge of computational geometry that is becoming one of the significant forms of disciplinary 
background for design related professions. In encouraging tool-making protocols which incorporate material and 
performance manifestations beyond their descriptive nature, we are approaching what may truly be considered as 
performance-based computational geometry in the field of architectural design.

Optimization of structural form using a genetic algorithm to search associative parametric geometry

Conference Paper
Full-text available
Jul 2010



 Peter Von Buelow
 Andreas Falk
 Michela Turrin

Different methods using evolutionary computation (EC) have been successfully applied to structural form optimization for many years. A well known limitation of these methods is the computational effort required to analyze significantly large and complex systems. As a result most examples have been limited to simple truss forms or smaller aspects of overall structural systems. This is because the number of variables used to describe the structural geometry limits the size and complexity of problems that can be explored using EC methods. One solution to this limitation is the use of associative parametric models. In recent years use of parametric modeling software has become more widespread in architectural design. Parametric approaches to geometric modeling have the advantage that they are able to describe large, complex systems with very few variables. The reduced number of variables needed to describe geometric systems makes parametric models ideal for use with EC to explore optimal forms. This paper shows examples of how large, complex structural systems can be optimized for basic parameters like weight and number of components by combining a genetic algorithm with a finite element analysis and parametric modeling software. The procedure is outlined with specific applications. Examples show the use of this technique used to explore complex spatial structures. Results are shown with specific documentation of computational effort required.

Book
Jan 1999



 Yoshinari Miyamoto

Dr. Reneé G. Ford

Seven years have elapsed since Dr. Renee Ford, editor-in-chief of Materials Technology, first suggested to me to publish a book on Functionally Graded Materials (FGMs). She said that the FGM concept, then largely unknown outside of Japan and a relatively few laboratories elsewhere, would be of great interest to everyone working in the materials field because of its potentially universal applicability. There was no book about FGMs in English at that time, although the number of research papers, review articles, and FGM conference proceedings had been increasing yearly. We discussed what the book should cover, and decided it should present a comprehensive description from basic theory to the most recent applications of FGMs. This would make it useful both as an introduction to FGMs for those simply curious about what this new materials field was all about, and also as a textbook for researchers, engineers, and graduate students in various material fields. The FGM Forum in Japan generously offered to support this publication program. is very difficult for an individual author to write a book that Because it covers such a wide range of various aspects of many different materials, I invited more than 30 eminent materials scientists throughout the world, who were associated with FGM research, to contribute selected topics. I also asked several leading researchers in this field to edit selected chapters: Dr. Barry H. Rabin, then at the U. S.

Evolutionary Structural Optimization

Chapter
Jan 2002



 Yi Min Xie
X.Y. Yang
 Qing Quan Liang
 Osvaldo Querin

The evolutionary structural optimization (ESO) and basic ESO (BESO) processes and given various illustrative examples are described. Such processes are based on the concept of slowly removing inefficient materials from a structures so that the residual structure evolves towards the optimum. It is shown that the simple ESO and BESO algorithms are capable of solving a wide range of shape and topology optimization problems.

Multi-Commodity Flow-Based Spreading in a Commercial Analytic Placer
February 2019
 Nima Karimpour Darav
Andrew Kennings
Kristofer Vorwerk
Arun Kundu
Modern analytic placement tools are commonly built around the idea of iterative Lower Bound (LB) and Upper Bound (UB) placement. The LB step optimizes wirelength and timing while ignoring overlap and cell-type constraints, whereas the UB step attempts to spread cells and satisfy constraints without harming design quality. Top-down geometric partitioning techniques have traditionally been used to ... [Show full abstract] spread cells during UB placement. We propose a new, network flow-based approach for UB placement which does a better job of preserving quality by optimizing the displacement of cells from their LB positions. Our approach not only addresses cell overlap, but also accommodates complex region constraints and simultaneously spreads unit-sized logic, carry chains, and blocks like RAMs and DSPs. Our technique is scalable, does not require geometric partitioning, and is suitable for both flat and clustered placement flows.We deployed our algorithm in a commercial FPGA CAD flow, and show that it reduces HPWL by 6.4% on average (up to 22.8% in the best case) while improving worst-slack timing in over 90% of designs, compared to a state-of-the-art alternative.

Kenichi Morita
 Maurice Margenstern
 Katsunobu Imai
We define a hexagonal partitioned cellular automaton (HPCA), and study logical universality of a reversible HPCA. We give a specific 64-state reversible HPCA H 1 , and show that a Fredkin gate can be embedded in this cellular space. Since a Fredkin gate is known to be a universal logic element, logical universality of H 1 is concluded. Although the number of states of H 1 is greater than those of ... [Show full abstract] the previous models of reversible CAs having universality, the size of the configuration realizing a Fredkin gate is greatly reduced, and its local transition function is still simple. Comparison with the previous models, and open problems related to these model are also discussed. 1 Introduction A reversible cellular automaton (RCA) is a special type of CA such that every configuration (i.e., the whole state) of the cellular space has at most one predecessor, i.e., its global transition function is one-to-one. Such a system, as well as other reversible systems (e.g. a reversible Turing machi...
View full-text



Article
Full-text available

Logics and translations for hierarchical model checking
December 2017 · Procedia Computer Science
Norihiro Kamide
Ryu Yano
In this study, logics and translations for hierarchical model checking are developed based on linear-time temporal logic (LTL) and computation-tree logic (CTL). Hierarchical model checking is a model checking paradigm that can appropriately verify systems with hierarchical information and structures. A sequential linear-time temporal logic (sLTL) and a sequential computation-tree logic (sCTL), ... [Show full abstract] which can suitably represent hierarchical information and structures, are developed by extending LTL and CTL, respectively. Translations from sLTL and sCTL into LTL and CTL, respectively, are defined, and theorems for embedding sLTL and sCTL into LTL and CTL, respectively, are proved using these translations. These embedding theorems allow us to reuse the standard LTL- and CTL-based model checking algorithms to verify hierarchical systems that are modeled and specified by sLTL and sCTL.

</div>
<div class="nova-legacy-c-card__body nova-legacy-c-card__body--spacing-inherit"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-800 research-detail-middle-section__abstract" itemprop="description">The institutionalized separation between form, structure and material, deeply embedded in modernist design theory, paralleled by a methodological partitioning between modeling, analysis and fabrication, resulted in geometric-driven form generation. Such prioritization of form over material was carried into the development and design logic of CAD (Computer Aided Design). Today, under the imperatives and growing recognition of the failures and environmental liabilities of this approach, contemporary design culture is experiencing a shift of paradigm towards a material-aware design approach (Oxman,2007,Mele and Block,2010). This research aims to examine conceptual and modeling representations of an extended performative materiality and outline key areas of design applications for computationally enabled form generation.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

                                                <div class="rg-wayPoint" data-track-url="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/track/consume-asset?pid=235915606&lid=0fcfd5141c7664253e000000&fp=382a81257a65f137c51c8e7fa7e337192659170a&init=1"></div>

                        <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="1">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf2" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="2"><div class="pc pc2 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x1 y1 w0 h0 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Evangelos-Pantazis-2/publication/235915606/viewer/AS:103213340561409@1401619386248/background/2.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 y2 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Title: “Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3 ff2 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Applicant:<span class="ff3 ls0 ws4"> Pantazis Evangelos</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4 ff2 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Preferred<span class="_ _0"></span> Professorship<span class="_ _0"></span> at<span class="_ _0"> </span> ITA: <span class="_ _0"></span><span class="ff3">Assistant <span class="_ _0"></span>Chair <span class="_ _0"> </span>of <span class="_ _0"> </span>Building <span class="_ _0"> </span>Structure,prof.Dr. <span class="_ _0"> </span>P<span class="_ _1"></span>. <span class="_ _0"></span>Block <span class="_ _0"> </span>in <span class="_ _0"> </span>collaboration<span class="_ _0"></span> with  Chair<span class="_ _2"></span>  for </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Computer Aided Architectural <span class="_ _0"></span>Design, prof.<span class="_ _0"></span> Dr<span class="_ _1"></span> <span class="_ _0"> </span>L.<span class="_ _0"></span> Hovestadt<span class="_ _0"></span> and/or<span class="_ _1"></span> <span class="_ _0"></span>Chair<span class="_ _1"></span> <span class="_ _0"> </span>for Architecture<span class="_ _0"></span> and <span class="_ _0"></span>Digital Fabrication, <span class="_ _0"></span>prof F. </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Gramazio and M. Kohler.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7 ff2 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws1">Keywords:<span class="ff3 ws4"> <span class="_ _3"> </span>topology <span class="_ _3"> </span>optimization, <span class="_ _3"> </span>material <span class="_ _3"> </span>distribution <span class="_ _3"> </span>method, <span class="_ _3"> </span>architectural <span class="_ _3"> </span>design,<span class="_ _0"></span>  digital <span class="_ _3"> </span>fabrication, <span class="_ _3"> </span>additive </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">manufacturing, <span class="_ _0"></span>rapid <span class="_ _0"></span>prototyping, structural<span class="_ _0"></span> morphology,<span class="_ _0"></span> design <span class="_ _0"></span>explorer, design <span class="_ _0"></span>operator, variable <span class="_ _0"> </span>property<span class="_ _0"></span> fabrication, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">performance-based design</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 ya ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">1. Summary</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 yb ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Research topic: <span class="ff3 ls0">The institutionalized separation between form, structure and material, deeply embedded in modernist </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 yc ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">design theory, paralleled by a methodological partitioning between modeling, analysis and f<span class="_ _1"></span>abrication, resulted in </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 yd ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">geometric-driven form generation. Such prioritization of form over material was carried into the development and design </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ye ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">logic of CAD (Computer Aided Design). T<span class="_ _2"></span>oday, under the imperatives and growing recognition of the failures and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 yf ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">environmental liabilities of this approach, contemporary design culture is experiencing a shift of paradigm towards a </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y10 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">material-aware design approach (Oxman,2007,Mele and Block,2010). This research aims to examine conceptual and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y11 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">modeling representations of an extended performative materiality and outline key areas of design applications for </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y12 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">computationally enabled form generation.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y13 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Performance Based Design and <span class="ff2 ls1">Variable </span><span class="ls2">Material Property Distribution: </span><span class="ff3">Design can be described as a process of </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y14 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">emergence and discovery resulting from the definition of the constraints, their relationships, and the design problem. </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y15 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Constraints can help to focus design exploration through formulating the boundaries of available resources (Dritsas, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y16 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">2004). While they may initially prove to be a limitation, over the course of the design process they can evolve into a </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y17 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">driver for innovative design solutions. These solutions incorporate multiple manifestations of form, departing from the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y18 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">point of view of geometry, material selection, performance, and <span class="_ _1"></span>construction (Kilian,2006). Each manifestation promotes </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y19 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">its very own method of process and media of representation. However, in some cases representations may be generated </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">which support multiple manifestations simultaneously while reciprocally informing each other (Sass and Griffith,2006). </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Based on computational geometry, we can define certain analytical forms <span class="_ _1"></span>of representation in the form of “enabling </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">representations” which associate geometry to performance by means of generative computation processes (Oxman,</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">2007). Such enabling representations become design tools  offering multiple feasible translations based on a unifying </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">code of interpretation. These tools are intermediate in nature, a property which renders them generative. Beyond the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y1f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">notion of performance-driven interpretations based on computational geometry methods, this work will also deal with </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y20 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">computational analysis as a source for strategizing material distribution in design artifacts. This method promotes design </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y21 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">manifestations which are not concerned with the notion of “build-ability” to begin with, but they rather let formal </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y22 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">statements be informed by behavior and performance which result in the gradient distribution of material qualities and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y23 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">effects (Oxman, N.,2010)<span class="ls3">. </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y24 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Goals: <span class="ff3 ls0">This proposal, will engage topology optimization and material distribution methods in order to investigate </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y25 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">innovative architectural and design applications materialized by using additive fabrication technologies and functionally </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y26 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">graded materials. Rather than just breaking down the design into a series of digitally fabricated componentized elements </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y27 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">aiming at either simplified and straightforward or more complex assemblies, we suggest an alternative approach favoring </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y28 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">material distribution over strategies of composition. We will look into tunable mechanical properties created through </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y29 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">structural calibration or multi-material composition and will attempt to prove such an approach through the development </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">and realization of irregular digital geometries across multiple manufacturing scales. Each scheme will focus on specific </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">topologic, geometric and material constraints relating to the corresponding application.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 y2c ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls4 ws2">2. <span class="ls2 ws3">Methodology</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Performance driven design will be investigated as a theoretical and technical framework by which to model, analyze and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">fabricate objects with graded properties designed to correspond to multiple and continuously varied functional </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">constraints. In order to implement this approach as a fabrication process, we will focus on additive fabrication techniques </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y30 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">such as rapid manufacturing with Polyjet Matrix T<span class="_ _1"></span>echnology and customized fused deposition modeling. Experimental </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y31 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">designs employing suggested theoretical and technical frameworks, methods and techniques will be developed, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y32 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">discussed and demonstrated. They will promote product customization, rapid augmentation and variable property </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y33 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">prototyping. The research will be held and executed using both existing and custom developed software and hardware </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y34 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">platforms, with the aim of demonstrating the principles of variable property modeling in the design of products, building </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y35 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">components, and potentially larger constructions.  Three design schemes illustrated by corresponding design products </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y36 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">will be presented: a) Surface and Material: table design , b) Function and design: Bridge structure c) Form and forces: </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y37 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Self standing roofing structure.Each will demonstrate the approach in different scales while utilizing different modeling </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y38 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">strategies for the control of material properties based on performance constraints. In particular we will try to look into the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y39 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">topic through the following key aspects:</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3a ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">2.1.Virtual Modeling-Design Operators for variable property modeling </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h5 y3b ff5 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">121212_RESEARCH ST<span class="_ _1"></span>A<span class="_ _1"></span>TEMENT_”Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.647059,0.000000,0.000000,1.647059,0.000000,0.000000]}'></div>
</div>

                            </div>

                                            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="1">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf3" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="3"><div class="pc pc3 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x1 y1 w0 h0 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Evangelos-Pantazis-2/publication/235915606/viewer/AS:103213340561409@1401619386248/background/3.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3c ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">-T<span class="_ _1"></span>opology optimization/ Material distribution method:  <span class="ff3 ls0">The topology<span class="_ _1"></span>, shape, and size of the structure are not represented </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">by standard parametric functions but by a set of distributed functions defined on a fixed design domain. These functions </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">in turn represent a parametrization of the stiffness tensor of the continuum and it is the suitable choice of this </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">parametrization which leads to the proper design formulation for topology optimization. This method defines shape in </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y40 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">terms of a material density and geometry by what amounts to a raster representation as seen in computer graphics. </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y41 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">(Bendsoe, M.P<span class="_ _1"></span>. and Sigmund, O., 2003), Recent developments in material technologies and fabrication enable the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y42 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">realization of this notion. While given materials are bonded with the 'classical' notion of design, material design and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y43 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">"functionally graded materials" imply a broader range of material usage and design orientation. In terms of the optimizer </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y44 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">tool, heuristic methods will be employed as they are most flexible in complying with abstractly defined constraints and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y45 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">optimization objectives. Their flexibility lies in their ability to formulate a “fitness” or optimization function which does not </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y46 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">have to come in the form of an explicit analytic formula. In contrast to gradient based methods who call for smooth </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">functions, these methods can handle a complex analysis process, often functioning as a black box, which in our case will </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y47 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">be provided via the Finite Element analysis. Heuristic methods for evolutionary computation include Genetic Algorithms </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y48 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">(GA) (Goldberg 1989) often met in engineering problems (Chatzi et al. 201<span class="_ _1"></span>1, Fuggini et al. 2012), Particle Swarm </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y49 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Optimization (PSO) methods (Kennedy 1995) and several other alternatives (Michalewicz 1996). Evolutionary </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">computation has been previously used in architectural design optimization (Holzer et al. 2005) as well as in linking </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">optimal design to structural performance criteria (von Buelow et al. 2010, Rajan 1995). In those works however the focus </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">was on given material properties often accompanied by the associated limitations in selected geometries. This research </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">will attempt to shift the attention on the alteration of the material properties based on the implied geometrical and/or </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">functional parameters and vice versa.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y4f ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">-Finite Element analysis FEM-FEA: <span class="ff3 ls0">The finite element method (FEM) is a numerical technique for solving partial </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y50 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">differential or integral equations over complex domains. It is widely used in any field where numerical solution procedures </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y51 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">for initial/boundary value problems are needed to meet design and analysis needs. The FE method has become the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y52 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">most successful approximation method in engineering (Babuska 1973). Although the following list is not exhaustive, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y53 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">applications are met in structural mechanics, mechanical engineering, mechanics of materials, fluid mechanics, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y54 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">biomechanics, electrical engineering, aeronautical engineering, and environmental engineering and science. The aim is </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y55 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">to simulate physical behavior under structural and/or environmental loading cases. The method operates by applying a </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y56 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">mesh discretization of a continuous domain into a set of discrete sub-domains, usually called elements. Elements </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y57 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">comprise a set of different entities, linear, 2D, or 3D solid elements<span class="_ _1"></span>, chosen according to the nature of the problem at </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y58 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">hand, which enables partitioning a large problem into smaller parts that can be individually analyzed. Several attempts </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y59 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">have so far tried to couple FE analysis with optimization schemes, mainly aiming at optimization of structural </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">performance or topology optimization with a target of minimal weight (Adeli and Cheng  1994, Xie and Steven 1997). We </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">will follow this paradigm and try to further enhance the finite element method in an environment of material property </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">gradation goals like variable elasticity and minimal weight. The translation of a conceived<span class="ff7 ls2 ws5">!<span class="ff3 ws0">geometry</span>!</span>expressed in a CAD </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">form into a structural entity to be analyzed by FE analysis can be enabled by the use of voxels (Gröning et al. 2009).</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5e ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">-Voxels/ Maxels (material-voxels): <span class="ff3 ls0">V<span class="_ _1"></span>oxels are digital volume elements that are analogous to 2D pixels whose position is </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y5f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">defined by their proximity to other voxels. Voxels are thus good at representing regularly sampled spaces that are non-</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y60 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">homogeneously filled. They are currently used in the visualization and analysis of medical and scientific data but have </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y61 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">yet to be implemented in the context of form-generation. Maxel is a term introduced in 2005   to describe a physical voxel </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y62 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">(a portmanteau of the words 'material' and 'voxel'), which defines the build resolution of either a rapid prototyping or rapid </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y63 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">manufacturing process, or the resolution of a design produced by such fabrication means (Miyamoto et al. 1999). It is </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y64 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">also used in the context of the additive manufacturing processes (such as stereolithography<span class="_ _1"></span>, selective laser sintering, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y65 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">fused deposition modeling, etc.). We regard the “Voxel” to be a useful <span class="_ _1"></span>aid in rendering physically our digitally calculated </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h6 y66 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">models, through the use of rapid prototyping processes<span class="fs0 ls2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y67 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">The applicant is already in contact with the Chair of Structural Engineering at ETH Zurich, lead by Prof. Dr. E. Chatzi, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y68 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">who has experience in the combined use of optimization methodologies with structural analysis methods for the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y69 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">simulation of complex materials.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y6a ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">2.2. Physical Modeling- Tooling environment for variable property rapid prototyping</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Although there has been a significant development in additive fabrication technologies since they first appeared in the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">mid 1980’s, most of them still serve as prototyping technologies in the building industry<span class="_ _1"></span>.  Although they have provided the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">opportunity to create complex models they have been also very limiting, often reducing material selection to an array of </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">highly brittle, inelastic materials (Sachs,  Cima, et al., 1993). Thus, based on the latest achievements of Polyjet Matrix </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y6f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">TM technology, which allows for the creation of dual material prot<span class="_ _1"></span>otypes, we will focus on the varying property layered </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y70 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">manufacturing technology. <span class="_ _1"></span>The advantages of printing material with varied properties such as density or stiffness </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y71 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">variation are most significant as they can potentially enhance the mechanical performance of a given component while </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y72 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">reducing the overall amount of material required for its production (Oxman,2010). Accompanying an increased motivation<span class="_ _1"></span> </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y73 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">in the production of structural and highly functional graded parts using additive technologies, and inspired by pioneering </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y74 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">research into 3D fabrication of scaffolds for tissue engineering (Sun et al. 2004), our approach aims to combine 3D </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y75 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">printing with recent advancements achieved in material science and tissue engineering (Chua et al. 1999, Freyman et al. </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y76 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">2001, Cheah et al. 2003a,b, 2004). The distribution of material properties as a function of their performance </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y77 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">requirements at micro structural scale is elegantly exemplified with the development and application of functional </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y78 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">gradient materials (FGMs).We will try to implement and review the following techniques:</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h5 y3b ff5 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">121212_RESEARCH ST<span class="_ _1"></span>A<span class="_ _1"></span>TEMENT_”Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.647059,0.000000,0.000000,1.647059,0.000000,0.000000]}'></div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="2">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf4" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="4"><div class="pc pc4 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x1 y1 w0 h0 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Evangelos-Pantazis-2/publication/235915606/viewer/AS:103213340561409@1401619386248/background/4.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y3c ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">-Rapid Manufacturing/ Polyjet MatrixTM T<span class="_ _1"></span>echnology (Objet Geometries/): <span class="ff3 ls0">PolyJet Matrix technology is capable extruding </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y79 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">multiple photopolymers simultaneously and allows for the generation of composite material prototypes of varying </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">stiffness. With the use of this technology we will investigate the potential of altering the stiffness of one structure in critical </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">points so that we can improve its overall performance.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7c ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">-Fused Deposition Modeling/ Maker Bot (or similar custom 3d printer)& Kuka 6-axis robotic arm: <span class="ff3 ls0">Variable Fused </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Deposition Modeling will attempt to define a novel deposition technology, which of<span class="_ _1"></span>fers gradation control of materials </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y44 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">within one 3D print with the aim of increasing mechanical efficiency and reducing energy input. This technology will use a </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">robotic arm and a dynamic material feeder which will be able to mix and feed the prescribed material quantities/ratios. By </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y7f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">doing that, we hope to make a first step towards the introduction of FGMs into additive manufacturing, as well as freeing </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y80 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">this technique from the 2d sequential layering (added degrees of freedom if we attach a printing nozzle as the end </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y81 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">effector of the robot).</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y82 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">2.3. <span class="ls2">Functionally Graded Materials</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y83 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">In Material Science, functionally graded materials (FGMs) are characterized by the gradual variation in composition and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y84 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">structure over their volume, resulting in corresponding changes of the material’s properties. Such materials can be </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y85 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">designed and engineered for a specific set of functions and applications.(Suresh and Mortensen 1998). Functionally </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y86 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">graded materials are a new generation of engineering materials characterized by compositional and structural variation </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y87 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">across their volume unit, resulting in property changes in the material such as mechanical shock resistance, thermal </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y88 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">insulation, catalytic efficiency and relaxation of thermal stress. The concept of FGMs is revolutionary in the areas of </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y89 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">material science and mechanics as it allows one to fully integrate between material and structural considerations in the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">final design of structural components. (Stoneham and Harding 2009). As part of this research, functionally graded </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">materials will be the enabling tool for the realization of innovative designs and new structural forms.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 y8c ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">3. Aims and Objectives</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">This research aims at presenting the prospect for an emerging professional profile of <span class="ff8">informed tool-making </span><span class="ls2">in order to </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">promote a new model for contemplating form and practicing design. A<span class="_ _1"></span> new process, based on the gradient alteration of </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y8f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">material properties is suggested as a general approach to the design of building components. Finite Element analysis will </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y90 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">be the tool used for the simulation of potential designs and heuristic methods such as genetic algorithms or particle </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y91 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">swarm optimization will be used as the optimizer tools in order to achieve optimal design under the desired geometric, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y92 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">topological and material constraints. We will emphasize on the generative potential that exists within analytical tools for </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y93 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">geometrical evaluation, as we aim to prove that such tools may inform the designer in her/his search for formal </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y94 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">expression and that they contain opportunities to transcend the geometric-centered description of form by linking it to </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y95 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">performance criteria (spatial, structural, environmental, etc). Analytical tools will be computed as geometrical statements. </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y96 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">These statements will serve as multi-objective representations between geometry and performance, geometry and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y97 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">manufacturing as well as geometry and construction. For the materialization of such statements this work will examine </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y98 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">the PolyJet Matrix technology, which by extruding multiple photopolymers<span class="_ _1"></span> simultaneously, can allow for the variation of </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y99 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">material properties within one 3d print. Moreover, we will review FDM (fused deposition modeling) technology<span class="_ _1"></span>, a solid-</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9a ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">based fabrication process, by a) introducing multiple extrusion heads and b) by attaching them (along with the rest of the </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9b ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">hardware) as an end effector on a 6-axis robotic arm.</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 y29 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">4. Contribution</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">Computational tools associated with structural performance evaluation, simulation and optimization (FEM, Evolutionary </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9d ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">computation) are traditionally utilized outside the design process or in parallel to it. The model, presented in this paper<span class="_ _1"></span>, </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2c ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">seeks to integrate processes of performance evaluation with form generation by means of computational geometry<span class="_ _1"></span>. It will  </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9e ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">build upon research from material science and structural tectonics under novel fabrication tectonics, in order to suggest </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y9f ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">an approach for modeling and materializing a 3d object, where internal structure/composition of the form can be </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya0 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">represented by the corresponding variance of different material gradients. This ability can expand the potential of </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya1 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">prototyping, since the varying properties allows for optimization of material properties relative to their structural </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya2 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">performance and for more accurate evaluations of the intended final product (stress testing). If such a prospect is </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya3 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">legitimate, then it is the knowledge of computational geometry that is becoming one of the significant forms of disciplinary </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya4 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">background for design related professions. In encouraging tool-making protocols which incorporate material and </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 ya5 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">performance manifestations beyond their descriptive nature, we are approaching what may truly be considered as </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h6 ya6 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws4">performance-based computational geometry in the field of architectural design<span class="fs0 ls2">.</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h7 y74 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6">5.References/Bibliography</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h2 ya7 ff4 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">List of own relevant publications</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h5 y3b ff5 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">121212_RESEARCH ST<span class="_ _1"></span>A<span class="_ _1"></span>TEMENT_”Performance driven design and variable material property fabrication”</div>
</div>

<div class="t m0 x2 h3 yb0 ff3 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">- Adeli, H.<span class="ff7 ws5">!</span><span class="ls0 ws1">and</span><span class="ff7 ws5">!</span><span class="ls0">Cheng, N.</span><span class="ff7 ws5">!</span><span class="ls0 ws1">(1994).</span><span class="ff7 ws5">!</span><span class="ls0">“Augmented Lagrangian Genetic Algorithm for Structural Optimization.”</span><span class="ff7 ws5">!</span>J. <span class="_ _1"></span>Aerosp. </div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Michela-Turrin" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/273516591316998-1442222845657_Q64/Michela-Turrin.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Michela Turrin"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Michela Turrin</span></span></a></li>
</ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdba68611 lite-page-hidden">Different methods using evolutionary computation (EC) have been successfully applied to structural form optimization for many years. A well known limitation of these methods is the computational effort required to analyze significantly large and complex systems. As a result most examples have been limited to simple truss forms or smaller aspects of overall structural systems. This is because the number of variables used to describe the structural geometry limits the size and complexity of problems that can be explored using EC methods. One solution to this limitation is the use of associative parametric models. In recent years use of parametric modeling software has become more widespread in architectural design. Parametric approaches to geometric modeling have the advantage that they are able to describe large, complex systems with very few variables. The reduced number of variables needed to describe geometric systems makes parametric models ideal for use with EC to explore optimal forms. This paper shows examples of how large, complex structural systems can be optimized for basic parameters like weight and number of components by combining a genetic algorithm with a finite element analysis and parametric modeling software. The procedure is outlined with specific applications. Examples show the use of this technique used to explore complex spatial structures. Results are shown with specific documentation of computational effort required.</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdba673c7 lite-page-hidden">Seven years have elapsed since Dr. Renee Ford, editor-in-chief of Materials Technology, first suggested to me to publish a book on Functionally Graded Materials (FGMs). She said that the FGM concept, then largely unknown outside of Japan and a relatively few laboratories elsewhere, would be of great interest to everyone working in the materials field because of its potentially universal applicability. There was no book about FGMs in English at that time, although the number of research papers, review articles, and FGM conference proceedings had been increasing yearly. We discussed what the book should cover, and decided it should present a comprehensive description from basic theory to the most recent applications of FGMs. This would make it useful both as an introduction to FGMs for those simply curious about what this new materials field was all about, and also as a textbook for researchers, engineers, and graduate students in various material fields. The FGM Forum in Japan generously offered to support this publication program. is very difficult for an individual author to write a book that Because it covers such a wide range of various aspects of many different materials, I invited more than 30 eminent materials scientists throughout the world, who were associated with FGM research, to contribute selected topics. I also asked several leading researchers in this field to edit selected chapters: Dr. Barry H. Rabin, then at the U. S.</span></div>
</div>

<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdba680ab lite-page-hidden">The evolutionary structural optimization (ESO) and basic ESO (BESO) processes and given various illustrative examples are described. Such processes are based on the concept of slowly removing inefficient materials from a structures so that the residual structure evolves towards the optimum. It is shown that the simple ESO and BESO algorithms are capable of solving a wide range of shape and topology optimization problems.</span></div>

<div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span>February 2019</span></div>
<ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-auto"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/625176878256128-1526065191200_Q64/Nima-Karimpour-Darav.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Nima Karimpour Darav"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Nima-Karimpour-Darav" type="button" target="_blank">Nima Karimpour Darav</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Andrew-Kennings-42401537" type="button" target="_blank">Andrew Kennings</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Kristofer-Vorwerk-2153891722" type="button" target="_blank">Kristofer Vorwerk</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Arun-Kundu-28443537" type="button" target="_blank">Arun Kundu</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">Modern analytic placement tools are commonly built around the idea of iterative Lower Bound (LB) and Upper Bound (UB) placement. The LB step optimizes wirelength and timing while ignoring overlap and cell-type constraints, whereas the UB step attempts to spread cells and satisfy constraints without harming design quality. Top-down geometric partitioning techniques have traditionally been used to <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdba6888e","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdba6888e"> spread cells during UB placement. We propose a new, network flow-based approach for UB placement which does a better job of preserving quality by optimizing the displacement of cells from their LB positions. Our approach not only addresses cell overlap, but also accommodates complex region constraints and simultaneously spreads unit-sized logic, carry chains, and blocks like RAMs and DSPs. Our technique is scalable, does not require geometric partitioning, and is suitable for both flat and clustered placement flows.We deployed our algorithm in a commercial FPGA CAD flow, and show that it reduces HPWL by 6.4% on average (up to 22.8% in the best case) while improving worst-slack timing in over 90% of designs, compared to a state-of-the-art alternative.</span></div>

We give a specific 64-state reversible HPCA H 1 , and show that a Fredkin gate can be embedded in this cellular space. Since a Fredkin gate is known to be a universal logic element, logical universality of H 1 is concluded. Although the number of states of H 1 is greater than those of <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdba693ce","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdba693ce"> the previous models of reversible CAs having universality, the size of the configuration realizing a Fredkin gate is greatly reduced, and its local transition function is still simple. Comparison with the previous models, and open problems related to these model are also discussed. 1 Introduction A reversible cellular automaton (RCA) is a special type of CA such that every configuration (i.e., the whole state) of the cellular space has at most one predecessor, i.e., its global transition function is one-to-one. Such a system, as well as other reversible systems (e.g. a reversible Turing machi...</span></div>

<h3 class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit publication-recommendation-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare gtm-recommendation-item-link" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/publication/319446210_Logics_and_translations_for_hierarchical_model_checking" target="_blank">Logics and translations for hierarchical model checking</a></h3>
<div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span>December 2017</span> · <span>Procedia Computer Science</span></div>
<ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-auto"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Norihiro-Kamide-70240934" type="button" target="_blank">Norihiro Kamide</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Ryu-Yano-2132388002" type="button" target="_blank">Ryu Yano</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">In this study, logics and translations for hierarchical model checking are developed based on linear-time temporal logic (LTL) and computation-tree logic (CTL). Hierarchical model checking is a model checking paradigm that can appropriately verify systems with hierarchical information and structures. A sequential linear-time temporal logic (sLTL) and a sequential computation-tree logic (sCTL), <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdba6977f","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdba6977f"> which can suitably represent hierarchical information and structures, are developed by extending LTL and CTL, respectively. Translations from sLTL and sCTL into LTL and CTL, respectively, are defined, and theorems for embedding sLTL and sCTL into LTL and CTL, respectively, are proved using these translations. These embedding theorems allow us to reuse the standard LTL- and CTL-based model checking algorithms to verify hierarchical systems that are modeled and specified by sLTL and sCTL.</span></div>
